Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Integrating genetics, life history, and morphology to understand the diversification of an enigmatic metazoan lineage
Award.AbstractNarration:
Rotifers are critical members of freshwater communities because of their important roles in energy and nutrient cycling. Rotifers have also proven to be valuable models for aging and toxicology studies, and are a key early diverging lineage for understanding the pattern of evolution within the animal clade. Despite this importance, rotifer species remain difficult to identify and few phylogenetic relationships within the clade are well supported. This collaborative effort linking researchers at the University of Texas El Paso, University of Massachusetts Lowell and Ripon College will increase phylogenetic and taxonomic resolution within phylum Rotifera by using a combination of advanced molecular and morphological techniques. This research will result in a new phylogenetic classification for the clade, in addition to insights into the rates of molecular evolution and the rates and drivers of cryptic speciation within the rotifer lineage.

The project will provide scientific training focused on rotifer systematics to graduate and undergraduate students at each of the three collaborating institutions. An undergraduate laboratory module, newly designed museum exhibit, and scientific workshops will all help disseminate the results broadly. The public will be able to access an interactive tutorial and key to rotifer species, plus other results from the project via the Encyclopedia of Life website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary: Phylum Rotifera comprises >2000 species of tiny, animals that play important roles in energy and nutrient cycling in freshwaters. They also are vital to understanding animal evolution, including evolution of sex, and are important models for aging and toxicology studies. This research undertook a comprehensive investigation of an important, but poorly known group within the rotifers, superorder Gnesiotrocha.

Intellectual Merit — The collaborative effort of the three researchers had four goals.

Goal 1. To produce a molecular robust phylogeny and classification of superorder Gnesiotrocha. In this goal CoPI-Wallace’s supplied the other PIs with live samples from WI and SC. He also acted as a taxonomic expert to aid in, and/or to confirmation, species identification of species. In addition CoPI-Wallace was an author on a paper dealing with the molecular phylogeny of a cryptic species complex in phylum Rotifera: Mills, S. et al. 2017. Hydrobiologia (doi:10.1007/s10750-016-2725-7). Wallace also consulted with PI-Walsh and one of her PhD students on developing a combined morphological/molecular phylogeny of the gnesiotrochan genus Limnias.

Goal 2. To investigate the evolution of gnesiotrochan body forms and life histories. CoPI-Wallace was an author on three publications: one published; two in press.

1. Hochberg, Walsh, & Wallace. 2017. Invertebrate Biology 136:50–61. (doi:10.1111/ivb.12161).

2. Walsh, May, & Wallace. (in press). Hydrobiologia (doi:10.1007/s10750-016-2712-z). [This work includes a database on the morphology of diapausing embryos (resting eggs) of rotifers.]

3. Sarma, Jiménez-Santos, Nandini, & Wallace. (in press). Hydrobiologia (doi:10.1007/s10750-017-3184-5).

Goal 3. To analyze the structure and function of the gnesiotrochan trophi. CoPI-Wallace worked on several aspects of gnesiotrochan anatomy one with an undergraduate McNair Scholar.

1. Marema, Megan. 2016. Modeling rotifer jaws using mass spring systems. (Undergraduate thesis, A.B. degree, Ripon College, Ripon, WI.)  [McNair Scholar; CoPI-Wallace supervised, in part.]

2. Wallace, Snell, & Smith. 2015. Phylum Rotifera. Elsevier. ISBN:978-0-12-385026-3.

Goal 4. To improve the infrastructure of scientific training in rotifer taxonomy by producing keys to the Rotifera. This goal was delayed so that CoPI-Wallace had time to complete three chapters in the 4th edition of the series Thorp & Covich's Freshwater Invertebrates. Another taxonomy paper is in preparation that deals with the gnesiotrochan genus Limnias. After that Wallace will take up developing keys to several other gnesiotrochan genera that have not been revised in decades and then will start developing the electronic keys.

1. Allen, Wallace, & Sisson. 2016. Zebrafish 13:281–286. (doi:10.1089/zeb.2015.1182).  [McNair Scholar, CoPI-Wallace supervised, in part.]

2. José de Paggi, Wallace, Fontaneto, & Marinone. (In review). Phylum Rotifera: Keys to Neotropical fauna. Elsevier, NY.

3. Segers, DeSmet, Fontaneto, Hinz, Hussey, Michaloudi, Wallace, & Jersabek. 2016. Zootaxa 4066(1):81–82. (doi:10.11646/zootaxa.4066.1.7).

4. Wallace, R.L., T. Snell, E. J. Walsh, S. S. S. Sarma and H. Segers, 2016. Phylum Rotifera: Keys to Nearctic fauna. Elsevier, NY. ISBN:978-0-12-385028-7.

5. Wallace, R.L., T. Snell, E.J. Walsh, S.S.S. Sarma and H. Segers. (In press). Phylum Rotifera: Keys to Palearctic fauna. Elsevier, NY.

Broader Impacts — NSF’s broader impact goals are to promote teaching, training, & learning, & expand participation of underrepresented groups; disseminate our results to a wide audience; enhance the infrastructure for research and education. 

Teaching, training, & learning, & expanding participation of underrepresented groups. CoPI-Wallace mentored 17 students at Ripon College to completion of their undergraduate thesis: i.e., 7 female & 10 male; 4 were McNair Scholars (2 female & 2 male). He also served on PhD and MS committees for students at The University of Texas at El Paso (1 MS; 3 PhD) and the University of Massachusetts at Lowell (1 MS; 1 PhD).

Disseminate our results to a wide audience. In addition to scientific papers (see above), CoPI-Wallace has been asked to revise a previously published chapter on rotifers (Academic Press; Encyclopedia of Reproduction). He also has worked with one, or both, of the other PIs to organize and run three special sessions at scientific meetings.

1. Society of Integrative and Comparative Biology: Soft bodies, hard jaws: phylogenetic diversity of prey capture and processing in jawed, soft-bodied invertebrates. Spring 2015.

2. International Rotifer Symposium: Resting eggs, dormancy, and egg banks. 14th International Rotifer Symposium Czech Republic. Summer 2015.

3. American Society of Limnology and Oceanography: Temporal and spatial components affecting zooplankton community structure. Winter 2017.

Enhancing the infrastructure for research and education. CoPI-Wallace advanced this goal in several ways .  

1. PI-Walsh, with CoPI-Wallace's help, developed a museum display on invertebrate jaws that was displayed for several months in UTEP's Centennial Museum.

2. Six news articles were published in SILNews, the newsletter of the International Society of Limnology.

3. In January 2014 & November 2016 CoPI-Wallace gave a week long lecture series on rotifers to the faculty and graduate students of the Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México.

4. Wallace worked with a local HS teacher who supervised >4 students over the course of this grant.
